Topic.Title: NTWK $5.7 Up 5%…….Breakout Alert……Rally Just Getting Started….Monster Earnings/Guidance Last Week……. Huge Cloud Division Growth of This Global Software Being Recognized……Likely Acquisition Target…..Guided for 40% Revenue Growth and $1/share Net Income in 2013…..Expects Revenues and Net Income to Double by 2015…….3M Share Float….Target Raised to $16/share Average and $21/share max After earnings....Trading at 20% of Sector Averages…..$10 Short term target.......Radar it!!

Message.Msg: Analyst Upgraded NTWK over the weekend.....Summary of Research Note: 12-month price target of $11.00 per share. Our price target is based on the average forward 2013 P/E multiple of 13.2X (up from 12.8X in August 2012). For industry comparables see table below. NTWK is trading at 6.4X our FY13 EPS forecast of $0.85 per share. We applied an 11X multiple to our FY13 EPS forecast. We anticipate a richer multiple as earnings momentum builds in FY13. NTWK’s discount to its peers most likely stems from poor 1H12 results. ==== Basis of Forecast Projected sales consist of fees from licensing, maintenance and services, and Vrozzi e-commerce division revenue. Software consulting and implementation services should account for approximately 49% of total sales. We project compounded annual growth in services of 13% to FY14 from FY10 reflecting 80 significant customers in FY14, up from 52, 37, and 28 in FY12, FY11, and FY10, respectively. Growth will be supported by an estimated 30 potential NFS customers located in China, Japan, Malaysia, Thailand, the US, and the United Kingdom. The company is entering FY13 with a $25 million backlog and approximately $100 million in qualified leads. One quarter of the backlog is from four new NFS platform customer implementations that began in 4Q12. In August 2011, NetSol launched its Cloud Vrooz Divisioni, an e-procurement search tool for SAP supplier relationship management (SRM) users. SAP AG is a global vendor of enterprise management systems that has the largest market share (24%) based on a worldwide Gartner survey. Vroozi should provide sales diversification and a higher margin recurring revenue stream. The Vroozi division contributed $1.3 million in FY12 sales. We forecast at least eleven additional implementations in FY12, which should contribute at least $4 million to sales during FY13 and $6 million to FY14. The company announced the launch of a second cloud division in September 2012 offering a new set of products and services that utilize their software development capabilities and significant cloud infrestrusctures We anticipate FY13 and FY14 gross and operating margins will improve to at least 60% and 19%, and 61% and 19.6%, respectively, due to Vroozi and NFS platform sales gains.

Message.Title: 258.75 somewhat critical.
Message.Msg: To people like me who want to go long. To shorts here, it doesn't matter. They remain in the red indefinitely.

"Having been an entrepreneur for a decade, the pain from financial losses is trivial." Good, so when your losses go from a little sad to tragic the pain won't bother you as much. Pain is a good indicator; it causes one pause to change directions and do the right thing instead of continuing down the wrong path. Like when a child suffers a minor burn when playing with matches... "Ever had to let 75% of your people go?" Ever make such a mess of business where you had to let 75% of your people go? Borders had to do something like that. And they were up against Amazon. Umm, like you. "I could lose all my money and start over just fine. I'm very lucky." You're conflating the past with the future. Everyone who shorts Amazon thinks they're lucky until the day they get squashed, as your $230 short is in the process of getting squashed right now. "I went to Kellogg in the late 90's when it was ranked #1 blah, blah, blah..." This has nothing to do with investing, as usually, and only serves to illustrate my point that even people who brag and claim to be intelligent can prove absolute imbeciles when it comes to making good investments.

Message.Title: CMG moving up quietly
Message.Msg: wonder why CNBC is not talking about the turn around ? Don't let the retail have cheap shares ?? Maybe???
Don't go long on CMG. Just when you think it's safe to buy it, it will get swatted. Bwahahahaha . . .

Yes,edison, pigs short AMZN and lose a lot of money. You really think he's honest about making money??? Given he's claimed to have bough DITM puts early on most everything he's been bearish on I doubt he has much money. What do you say we track Techyboy's performance????

"I could lose all my money and start over just fine. I'm very lucky." Let me guess . . . Is this pretty much what happened, techstrategy? You started a company during the bubble phase, got hit by the 2007/2008 financial crisis, went almost bankrupt, got a grant or something from the government to keep your downsized business, and have been playing with the stock market with our tax money. Is that why you feel lucky? Techstrategy is one of those who benefited from the last bubble (and subsequent bail-out by the U.S. government) we had. What a shame!

ZERO DEBT....i've had a business for 16 years and started it without a loan. 8100 jobs completed and it has been a wonderful blessing. Bought a house in 75 for 24,950 and another one for 210k a month before 9/11. The 2nd one is a large, private split level that sits on 5/8ths of an acre. my son and two renters helped pay it off. The renters are gone and it also is paid off. ZERO DEBT is the target you should be shooting at....

I won't sink to the level of you and Geeg. I don't wish bad things upon you nor will I try to be abusive. No doubt, I've made plenty of mistakes in trying to build my business. But, it goes well beyond that. The aggressive industrial policy in Asian nations explicitly targeting technology have structurally altered the return profile and has systematically undermined the emerging technology businesses that have historically powered our nations innovation and productivity growth. As a result, investments in commercializing fundamental scientific innovation has declined significantly in real terms, particularly in the VC sector where everything shifted to social media / apps where a small investment could be flipped to IPO rapidly to leave someone else holding the bag. Unless we reverse the dynamics at work, it will hurt all of us. We'll see how this plays out.
Nemisis, how did techyboy claim to short AMZN, ITM puts? I'm trying to start tracking his realtime performance and comparing it to a bullish option position.

Geeg, I have my own capital at risk in the business and in the market. And contrary to your assertion, emerging technology companies didn't get a bailout in the crisis. The banks did. Early stage science companies in particular saw VC funding scaled back as VC's refocused on the most mature in the portfolio in the hopes of getting them to the IPO stage. Is there are reason you feel compelled to try to attack and abuse me? It seems that you, Nemesis and even Ski seem to try to employ the attack the messenger strategy to obfuscate the reality that Amazon is both overvalued and surprisingly vulnerable....

Ski: Last year, I rode AMZN down from 240 to about $175, but that is in the past. In the current wave, I bought an evenly $ weighted mix when AMZN hit $228 before earning and sold all of the OOM puts when AMZN hit $215 before earnings and vol was at a peak. I held the DITM contracts. On those, I have taken a bath and it goes without saying that ANYONE holding a bullish option position has massively outperformed over the past few months... The questions isn't where we are today. It is where we will be when I either choose to or am forced to (which isn't a remote possibility at this point) exit my positions... Just as you were killing me as CMG rose from $340 to $450, I ultimately made a killing when I rode my DITM puts down to $280...

Topic.Title: Shorts, short now. Here's one of the greatest shorting opportunity!

Message.Msg: Great job shorting, Your making money

On his recent/current $230 short he claims to own DITM puts. I think he admitted this when the stock was only a little above that level and believed it would soon be far below $230 after the recent earnings. But this did not happen leaving him with a big fat loss. His past shorts are mostly reported after the fact and do not always disclose how he shorted them. I don't consider any of that relevant or reliable. The normal pattern with these kinds of really stubborn shorts is the same pattern. Stage 1: Make up stuff after the fact. Stage 2: After losing lots of money or suffering large paper losses, switch to saying you have only leap options, i.e., you kick the can of your heavy losses down the road. Stage 3: Silence when you realize you are not "lucky" here, and you realize big losses in your trading account.

Message.Msg: Bullish chart....bullish technicals....this one is about to pop big time

Yeah, shorts here never lose money! They always make money! Do you remember panichomo2? She had been a perma-bear here for decades but whenever AMZN bounced nicely and stayed up for some prolonged period of time, she came out and said that she covered at the lows before the bounce took place. She got wiped out on April 27th of this year, by the way. She wrote naked calls before the earnings on April 26th. She lost her house shortly after that day and became homeless. She made a brief appearance again before the last earning, July 27th. It was very short-lived, however. She bought two deeply out-of=the-money puts after saving up a portion of her welfare checks before that date, and of course, she got wiped out again. The last time I heard, she was institutionalized. The trauma of losing a house and getting wiped out again in just about three months was just too much for her. Amen.

Message.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move
Message.Msg: Morgan Stanley issued a derivative (i.e. "Contingent Income Auto-Callable Securities") that helps the buyer/seller bet on the move of Amazon. HSBC did something similar recently, and I read this as a negative sentiment on Amazon. If Amazon moves up from or stays at 75% of its recent level of $255.63 (i.e. $191.73) the security pays basically 14% for a year (plus the original par amount). If Amazon goes down from $191.73, the security holder gets a negative return. See Edgar filing below. (edgar root) /Archives/edgar/data/895421/000095010312004790/dp32887_fwp-ps330.htm (edgar root) /Archives/edgar/data/895421/000095010312004204/dp31835_424b2-autocallable.htm Who knows who is buying this security, but when I see someone paying 14% return contingent on Amazon going up, but EARNING money on Amazon going down from $191.73, I think that there are some hedge funds out there ready to burst the Amazon bubble. Maybe my reading on this is totally wrong, but I don't see people paying 14% on anything unless they think it's not going to happen. Maybe this is just some crazy hedging instrument designed by a hedge fund to arbitrage the crazy option values and the actual volatility of the stock, who knows. FYI, I think Amazon has an awesome business model long run, and long-term I fancy it a great investment (as a former employee). But it's recent run-up is completely detached from the economic fundamentals. They are building some great scale-able business models and the Kindle platform (the sub-par Fire aside) is a fat-margin business with great potential, as is web-services. But there are too many opportunities to stumble in the next 3 years to justify a 100X forward P/E multiple. Talent is stretched at Amazon right now, the company is betting in areas that they are out-classed (like tablets), and frankly has too many bets placed. They're going to slip soon (probably when the Fire sells less than they expected) and when the insiders start chattering to the press and blogs like they always do, they stock will fall.
